questions.text: You have given a supraclavicular block in a patient for an upper limb surgery, following which the patient complains of difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Although all these complications are possible with a supraclavicular block, the most common complication is ipsilateral phrenic nerve palsy.
  • Nearly half of patients undergoing supraclavicular block will experience ipsilateral phrenic nerve palsy, although ultrasound guidance may decrease this incidence by allowing the use of minimal local anaesthetic volume
  • The supraclavicular approach to the brachial plexus is a regional anaesthesia technique used to block the nerves of the upper limb. It involves accessing the brachial plexus at the level where its roots, trunks, and divisions are closely grouped, just above the clavicle.

choices.text: Higher frequency ultrasound probes are used for deeper penetration
High-frequency ultrasound probes provide for higher image resolution
Liner array probes are typically used for imaging deeper anatomical structures
The curvilinear probe is designed to image superficial structures best

questions.text: The most correct statement regarding the appropriate use of ultrasound equipment during the performance of regional anaesthesia is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • High-frequency ultrasound probes are typically manufactured with a linear probe design, providing high image resolution for superficial anatomical structures. (Options A & C ruled out)
  • Low-frequency ultrasound probe equipment is typically produced with a curvilinear probe design and reveals a lower image resolution, but is used for visualising deeper anatomical structures due to better penetration. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: When performing an axillary block of the brachial plexus for distal upper extremity surgery, which of the following nerves most often needs to be targeted separately?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The musculocutaneous nerve typically branches off more proximally than the axillary approach of brachial plexus blockade. It is frequently not adequately anaesthetised with a traditional axillary block of the plexus, so it most often needs to be targeted separately (local anaesthetics are deposited around the axillary artery).

Musculocutaneous Nerve Block

Site:

  • Within the coracobrachialis muscle or between the biceps and the coracobrachialis muscle,
  • Located lateral to the axillary artery in the proximal arm.

Indication:

  • To supplement axillary brachial plexus block for complete distal upper limb anaesthesia
  • Prevents tourniquet pain on the lateral forearm
  • Important for forearm and hand surgeries, where the axillary block alone may miss this nerve

Complication:

  • Incomplete anaesthesia if not separately blocked
  • Tourniquet pain in the lateral forearm
  • Rarely, intramuscular injection discomfort or transient nerve irritation
  • The median, ulnar, and radial nerves, along with the axillary artery and vein, are enclosed within a common connective tissue sheath in the axilla and can be blocked with a single injection in the neurovascular sheath (Options A, B & D ruled out)

questions.text: Which nerve block is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows an intercostobrachial nerve block.

Site:

  • Originates from the T2 nerve root
  • Becomes superficial on the medial aspect of the proximal arm
  • Performed with the patient supine, arm abducted and externally rotated
  • Field block given in a linear path from deltoid prominence down the medial arm using 5 mL of local anaesthetic.

Indication:

  • Supplement to brachial plexus block for complete anaesthesia of the medial upper arm
  • Prevents tourniquet pain during upper limb surgeries
  • Useful in axillary surgeries, brachioplasty, or vascular access procedures in the upper arm

Complication: An Incomplete block may result in residual medial arm pain

  • Risk of local anaesthetic systemic toxicity if injected intravascularly
  • Potential for hematoma or bruising at the injection site

Explanation for other options:

Musculocutaneous Nerve Block (Option A):

  • The nerve is typically located within the coracobrachialis muscle or between the biceps and coracobrachialis and is lateral to the axillary artery at the proximal arm.
  • Used as a supplement to the axillary block to provide anaesthesia to the lateral forearm, also prevents tourniquet pain in upper limb surgery.

Median Nerve Block (Option B):

  • Injected at the elbow - medial to the brachial artery in the antecubital fossa, and at the wrist - between the palmaris longus and flexor carpi radialis tendons.
  • Used for procedures on the thumb, index, middle fingers, and lateral palm, like carpal tunnel release and hand surgeries.

Ulnar Nerve Block (Option C):

  • Injected at the elbow - posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus (cubital tunnel) and at the wrist - lateral to the flexor carpi ulnaris tendon and proximal to the pisiform bone
  • Used for Procedures involving the ring and little fingers and the medial hand.
  • Often used with other terminal nerve blocks for hand surgeries.

choices.text: Access to resuscitation medications and equipment
Immediate access to a mechanical ventilator

questions.text: While performing a peripheral nerve block in an awake patient, access and/or use of all of the following should be considered mandatory, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Immediate access to a functioning anaesthesia ventilator is not always necessary while administering regional anaesthesia.
  • Regional anaesthesia must be performed in a monitored setting with standard ASA monitoring, including ECG, pulse oximetry, and non-invasive blood pressure. (Option B ruled out)
  • Supplemental oxygen, along with resuscitative medications and equipment, should be readily accessible and immediately available. (Option A and Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recognised complication of an interscalene brachial plexus block?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Wrist drop is not a recognised complication of interscalene block. It results from radial nerve injury, which is a distal nerve and not typically affected at the root/trunk level targeted in interscalene blocks.

Interscalene Brachial Plexus Block

Site:

  • Targeted at the roots/trunks of the brachial plexus
  • Located between the anterior and middle scalene muscles at the level of C6 (near the cricoid cartilage)
  • Typically visualised using ultrasound guidance

Advantage:

  • Provides dense anaesthesia for the shoulder and upper arm
  • Superficial and easy to perform with ultrasound
  • Often results in rapid onset and excellent muscle relaxation
  • Can also block supraclavicular nerves, adding to shoulder coverage

Indication:

  • Shoulder surgery (e.g., rotator cuff repair, shoulder arthroscopy)
  • Clavicle and proximal humerus fractures
  • Manipulation of frozen shoulder
  • Any surgery involving the upper arm, especially the proximal regions

Complication:

  • Phrenic nerve paralysis → hemidiaphragmatic paresis (very common) (Option A ruled out)
  • Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) (Option B ruled out)
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve block → hoarseness
  • Vascular puncture or hematoma
  • Seizures if intravascular injection occurs
  • Rare: pneumothorax (Option C ruled out), high spinal block, or brachial plexus injury

choices.text: Administer local anaesthetic at this point

questions.text: You are performing an axillary brachial plexus block using a peripheral nerve stimulator. At a current of 0.5 mA, a motor response is elicited. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image is that of a peripheral nerve stimulator used for performing nerve stimulator-guided blocks of peripheral nerves.
  • The occurrence of a motor response at 0.5 mA (0.1 ms) indicates needle-nerve contact or intraneural needle placement. So, the next ideal step would be to withdraw the needle by 1mm.

Peripheral Nerve Stimulator:

It is used to locate peripheral nerves for regional anaesthesia by eliciting a motor response to electrical stimulation.

Motor Response & Current Thresholds:

If Motor Response Occurs at 0.5 mA or Less:

This suggests needle-nerve contact or possible intraneural placement, which carries a risk of nerve injury.

  1. Stop Needle Advancement Immediately
    • Prevent further risk of nerve trauma.
  2. Withdraw the Needle by ~1 mm. Advancing the needle may cause injury (Option B ruled out)
    • This minimises the risk of intraneural injection. (Option C ruled out)
  3. Check Opening Injection Pressure
    • Use a pressure monitor or feel for resistance.
    • If pressure > 15 psi, do not inject (suggests intrafascicular location).
  4. Test with a Small Volume
    • Inject 1 mL of local anaesthetic if:
      • Motor response disappears
      • Opening pressure < 15 psi
  5. Reassess
    • If motor response persists or injection pressure remains high, reposition the needle further away from the nerve.
  • Never inject when:
    • There’s a strong motor response at ≤ 0.2 mA
    • Injection is painful or meets high resistance

questions.text: An ultrasound image obtained during a regional anaesthesia procedure is shown. Which of the following nerve blocks is most likely being performed?
After administering which of the following nerve blocks, would you expect the highest blood levels of local anaesthetic per local anaesthetic dose injected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The blood level of local anaesthetic (LA) after a nerve block depends on the vascularity of the injection site. More vascular areas absorb the anaesthetic faster into the bloodstream, increasing systemic levels.

So, from the given options intercostal nerve block has the highest blood levels of local anaesthetic per local anaesthetic dose injected

  • The intercostal block has one of the highest complication rates of any peripheral nerve block due to the proximity of the intercostal artery and vein(intravascular local anaesthetic injection), as well as underlying pleura (pneumothorax).
  • If multiple blocks are performed, care must be taken to avoid toxic levels of local anaesthetic.
  • Systemic absorption depends on
    1. Amount of local anaesthetic deposited
    2. Type of local anaesthetic
    3. Vascularity of the area
  • Sequence of systemic absorption of LA from highest to lowest:
    1. IVRA
    2. Tracheal
    3. Intercoastal block
    4. Paracervical block
    5. Caudal anaesthesia
    6. Lumbar epidural
    7. Brachial plexus (e.g., interscalene, axillary) (Option A and D)
    8. Sciatic nerve (e.g., popliteal) (Option B)
    9. Subcutaneous

questions.text:
Regarding the mode of regional anaesthesia given in the image below, mark the following statements true (t) or false (f).

A. Also called perineural local anaesthetic injection
B. Involves the placement of a percutaneous catheter inside a peripheral nerve
C. Helps in the prolongation of nerve blockade
D. Systemic local anaesthetic toxicity is a serious complication
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image represents the administration of a continuous peripheral nerve block by the placement of a catheter.
  • It is also termed perineural local anaesthetic
  • It involves the placement of a percutaneous catheter adjacent to a peripheral nerve, followed by local anaesthetic administration to prolong a nerve block.
  • Serious complications include systemic local anaesthetic toxicity, catheter retention, nerve injury, infection, and retroperitoneal hematoma formation.

questions.text: Match the following labels with the levels of brachial plexus blocks:
questions.solution: Explanation:

choices.text: Can provide surgical anesthesia for relatively short surgical procedures
Used for surgical procedures on extremities
For very short procedures, tourniquet must be deflated in immediate post-operative period

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intravenous regional anaesthesia is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Even in short procedures, the tourniquet must stay inflated for at least 15-20 minutes to prevent systemic toxicity.

Intravenous regional anaesthesia (IVRA):

  • Intravenous Regional Anaesthesia (IVRA) is also known as Bier's block.
  • Provides intense regional anaesthesia for 45-60 minutes.
  • Commonly used for short surgical procedures on the forearm, hand, or leg (e.g., carpal tunnel release).
  • An IV catheter is inserted on the dorsum of the hand (or foot).
  • A double pneumatic tourniquet is applied on the arm or forearm, below the knee, or on the thigh.
  • The limb is elevated and exsanguinated using an Esmarch elastic bandage (wrapped distal to proximal).
  • Local anaesthetic is injected after exsanguination.
  • Tourniquet must remain inflated for at least 15-20 minutes, even for short procedures, to prevent systemic toxicity from a rapid IV bolus.
  • Slow tourniquet deflation is recommended to enhance safety.

questions.text: You are administering an ankle block to a patient for great toe amputation. Which of the following nerves also has a motor nerve supply, as opposed to the others that are pure sensory nerves?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Superficial peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve, descends toward the ankle in the lateral compartment, giving motor branches to the muscles of eversion. It enters the ankle just lateral to the extensor digitorum longus and provides cutaneous sensation to the dorsum of the foot and toes.

Explanation for other options:

Saphenous nerve (Option A): It is a terminal branch of the femoral nerve and the only innervation of the foot that is not a part of the sciatic system. It supplies superficial sensation to the anteromedial foot and is most consistently located just anterior to the medial malleolus.

Sural nerve (Option B): It is a branch of the tibial nerve and enters the foot between the Achilles tendon and the lateral malleolus to provide sensation to the lateral foot.

The other 2 nerves blocked in the ankle block are the deep peroneal nerve and the posterior tibial nerve.

questions.text: After performing an axillary brachial plexus block, your ultrasound probe moves to scan laterally, and you see what appears to be an oval and hyperechoic nerve structure within the belly of the coracobrachialis muscle. When the needle tip is advanced closer to this structure and the nerve stimulator is activated, you notice that the elbow begins to flex. The most likely nerve branch that is being stimulated is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The musculocutaneous nerve is frequently found within the coracobrachialis muscle and/or between the biceps and coracobrachialis muscles. Stimulation of the musculocutaneous nerve will characteristically cause elbow flexion.

Explanation for other options:

Median nerve (Option A): Controls forearm flexors and some hand muscles

  • Enters the arm at the inferior border of the teres major
  • Runs with the brachial artery in the medial arm
  • Lies lateral to the artery initially, then crosses to become medial at the antecubital fossa
  • Travels between the biceps brachii and brachialis

Ulnar Nerve (Option B): Controls muscles of wrist and finger flexion, along with the majority of palm muscles

  • Lies medial to the axillary artery in the axilla
  • Leaves artery early → helps differentiate from MN during distal scanning
  • Travels in the medial anterior compartment of the arm
  • Pierces medial intermuscular septum → enters ulnar groove (posterior to medial epicondyle)

Radial Nerve (Option C): Controls elbow extension (via triceps)

  • Lies deep to the axillary artery, often hard to visualise (due to ultrasound artefact)
  • Passes posteriorly between the teres major and the long head of triceps
  • Enters the spiral groove of the humerus with the profunda brachii artery
  • Colour Doppler helps identify the accompanying artery

questions.text: Which of the following approaches to blockade of the brachial plexus by nerve stimulator technique is associated with the highest incidence of a pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Supraclavicular approach to blockade of the brachial plexus carries a high risk of pneumothorax, followed by the interscalene approach.

questions.text: An anaesthetic agent with a vasoconstrictor is contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An anaesthetic agent with a vasoconstrictor is contraindicated in the Ring block due to the risk of ischemia.

Vasoconstrictors (e.g., adrenaline/epinephrine) are commonly added to local anaesthetics (like lignocaine or bupivacaine) in various techniques such as spinal, epidural, and regional nerve blocks to:

  • Prolong the duration of anaesthesia by reducing systemic absorption
  • Reduce intraoperative bleeding
  • Delay systemic toxicity
  • Help detect intravascular injection (especially in epidurals-rise in HR = red flag)

Adrenaline is the most commonly used vasoconstrictor.

Felypressin is preferred in cardiovascular disease patients.

Ring block:

Ring blocks are used for digits (fingers, toes), penis, and pinna. They are supplied by end arteries with poor collateral flow.

  • Adding a vasoconstrictor in these areas can lead to:
    • Severe vasospasm
    • Ischemia
    • Tissue necrosis

Explanation:

A common indication for celiac block is abdominal malignancies causing visceral pain.

Site:

  • Located anterolateral to the aorta at the level of T12-L1 vertebral bodies
  • The celiac plexus lies posterior to the stomach and pancreas, and anterior to the crura of the diaphragm
  • Block is typically performed via a posterior (retrocrural) or anterior (transgastric) approach under fluoroscopy, CT, or ultrasound guidance.

Indications:

  • Severe upper abdominal pain, especially when refractory to opioids
  • Pancreatic cancer pain (most common indication)
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Other upper abdominal malignancies causing visceral pain

Complications:

  • Hypotension due to sympathetic blockade (most common)
  • Diarrhoea (from unopposed parasympathetic activity)
  • Transient back pain at the injection site
  • Bleeding or hematoma
  • Organ injury (kidney, aorta, bowel) if the needle placement is inaccurate
  • Neurological complications (rare): such as paraplegia due to spinal cord ischemia, if vascular injury occurs

Explanation for other options:

Chest pain (Option B) - Managed by sympathetic or intercostal blocks.

Sciatica (Option C) - Treated with epidural injections or sciatic nerve blocks.

Perineal pain (Option D) - Managed with pudendal nerve or caudal epidural blocks.
